picked: To determine how many measures this note pattern takes up in a time signature of 3/4, we need to count the total number of quarter notes (QN) it contains and divide by the number of beats per measure (BPM). The BPM for 3/4 is 120. If there were x QN, then the result would be x/36 = y (since each beat has a duration of 1/36), and dividing both sides by 36 gives us x=y*36 = 120*y. Finally, if the total number of QN was z, we have z=x-x/36+x/72-x/144+... where each term represents one kind of note with its fractional duration. Summing these fractions for all kinds of notes produces z=(8/36 + 4/9 + 5/9 + 1/4 + 5/27 - 1/4 * 72/144)z + ... which can be simplified as 2(z)= 120*y, or finally z = 120*y / 2. Therefore, the total number of measures needed for this pattern will be z / y. In other words, the answer will depend on the exact value of y! Can you provide more information? Is this what you wanted?

data.sampled: The number of measures taken by this sequence depends on the length of each note value in terms of seconds (or milliseconds) as well as the BPM. For example if we assume all notes have duration of one second then at a standard tempo of 100BPM there will be 8 measure because 60*60=3600 seconds so 3600/8 = 450 for each measure meaning the first quarter is worth two measures, the next four eights make three more measures, followed by another two quarter and finally 8 sixteens which also constitute 2 measures leaving 2 measures left over after the last whole note has finished. If however the notes were to be held longer than a second or the BPM increased then less measures would be required to fit into a minute.
